title: Adding value to NLP: a little semantics goes a long way.

author: Diana Maynard, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield

Well, basically what we do is we basically trying to stick an ontology between the policymakers on one hand and the data on the other hand.
So we want to know which topics each document is talking about, which is essentially a problem of multi class classification.
And we have to connect these topics together in some coherent way.
So we used ontologies to basically connect information.

We automatically generate collections of keywords from them.

What's most representative?
Of the topic.

So if you have certain combinations of keywords, you get a better delineation of the topic and then for each document we decide which topics best fit it.

Not fully automated, because this kind of approach still requires a little bit of manual intervention for best results, and of course language processing is never 100% accurate, so there are some issues still, and it's also really hard to evaluate to know whether it's good enough and when when we stop tweaking it, so determining waiting mechanisms, cutoff thresholds and so on is a kind of constant problem.

'cause I would have expected the opposite.

I mean that you know the community as a whole.

My point is, it doesn't always need to be that complex, it just needs to be applied.
And this is what we spend a lot of time doing.
Now we've got some quite well established frameworks for doing NLP for doing social media analysis and so on for linking to ontologies and so on.

So we do a lot of applied stuff in various domains and what I find really surprising still is there's a number of areas where these technologies are really, really unknown, so some of the some of the areas we're working at the moment where again this stuff is is really quite new to them, so some of the areas of journalism a lot in the politics domain in the legal domain, legal AI is becoming a very hot topic at the moment, but again there I mean a lot of the people we work with, they have no at the moment.
We're still not using any kind of NLP or or ontologies or anything, and there's a whole load of reasons why this might be humanities.

So my message, I guess, is don't neglect this kind of interdisciplinary borrowing.
I think we still got a lot of work to do to to disseminate this stuff to a lot of different application areas where.
Even just really simple stuff can really make a big difference.
